pages.text: Haikouichthys ercaicunensis comes from the middle Cambrian, with fossils found in the Qiongzhusi Formation, China. It is a small myllokunmingiid, growing up to 2.5 cm in length. Over 500 specimens are known, which has given palaeontologists a good look at its anatomy, for example it was amongst the earliest chordates with a defined skull, with it being postured as a basal stem-craniate. It is also suggested that it may have had the same brain divisions as modern

vertrebrates. The generic name dervies from the place name 'Haikou', near to where the fossils were found; and the Greek word 'ichthys', to mean 'fish'. The specific name derives from the place name of 'Ercaicun', again near to where the fossils were found; and the Latin word 'ensis', to mean 'belonging to'.
